article.title: Planck's view on the spectrum of the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect

multiple_choice_question.text: What effect do relativistic corrections have on the thermal SZ effect (tSZ) spectrum with increasing electron temperature?
choices: The tSZ \'null\' shifts towards lower frequencies.
The tSZ decrement and increment amplitudes increase.
The tSZ increment becomes narrower.
The tSZ \'null\' shifts towards higher frequencies and the decrement and increment amplitudes decrease while the increment becomes wider.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary purpose of the filter kernels shown in Figure 2?
choices: To identify point sources within galaxy clusters.
To enhance the signal-to-noise ratio of the tSZ signal from galaxy clusters.
To measure the redshift of galaxy clusters.
To estimate the optical depth of the intracluster medium.

multiple_choice_question.text: What selection criteria were applied to the Planck cluster catalogue to create the subsample shown in Figure 3?
choices: Clusters within 40% Galactic dust mask, with known low-frequency point sources, and large low-redshift systems were excluded.
All clusters were included regardless of location or properties.
Only clusters with confirmed spectroscopic redshifts were included.
Only clusters with high star formation rates were included.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the bottom two rows of Figure 4 illustrate compared to the top two rows?
choices: The effectiveness of matched filtering in removing contaminants from the stacked Planck HFI maps.
The difference between the tSZ signal and the FIR emission from galaxy clusters.
The impact of the kSZ effect on the stacked Planck HFI maps.
The evolution of the tSZ signal with redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the correlation matrix in Figure 5 represent?
choices: The spatial correlation between galaxy clusters in the sample.
The correlation between different frequency channels used in the data modeling.
The correlation between the tSZ signal and the FIR emission from galaxy clusters.
The correlation between the observed data and the best-fit model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 demonstrate about the matched filtering and spectral fitting pipeline?
choices: It produces biased estimates of the tSZ parameters.
It is highly sensitive to the presence of the kSZ effect.
It allows for an unbiased measurement of the tSZ parameters.
It is unable to distinguish between the tSZ signal and the FIR emission from galaxy clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding presented in Figure 7?
choices: The FIR emission from galaxy clusters is negligible.
The tSZ signal is not detected in the simulated data.
The simulated data can be well fit by a two-component model consisting of a tSZ spectrum with relativistic corrections and a model for the expected FIR emission from galaxy clusters.
The kSZ effect dominates the signal in the simulated data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What bias is illustrated in Figure 8?
choices: The bias in the electron temperature measurement due to the kSZ effect.
The bias in the Comptonization parameter (Y) due to using the non-relativistic approximation of the tSZ spectrum.
The bias in the FIR emission measurement due to Galactic foregrounds.
The bias in the cluster mass measurement due to the hydrostatic mass bias.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the detection of the tSZ signal in the real data, as shown in Figure 9?
choices: 5σ

multiple_choice_question.text: Compared to the full sample, what is the significance of the relativistic tSZ signal detection in the subsample of the 100 hottest clusters, as shown in Figure 10?
choices: Significantly higher.
Slightly higher.
Roughly the same.
Slightly reduced.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 11 demonstrate about matched filtering compared to aperture photometry for extracting the stacked spectrum of galaxy clusters?
choices: Matched filtering leads to larger errorbars and enhances the contribution from cluster FIR emission.
Both methods perform equally well.
Aperture photometry is a more robust method for foreground removal.
Matched filtering allows for less Galactic foreground residuals and reduces the contribution from cluster FIR emission to the extracted spectrum.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of the CCAT-prime survey compared to Planck for constraining the cluster SZ parameters, as shown in Figure 12?
choices: CCAT-prime has a wider frequency coverage.
CCAT-prime is less sensitive to atmospheric noise.
CCAT-prime has roughly one order of magnitude better sensitivity in the 95–405 GHz frequency range.
CCAT-prime is a space-based mission, while Planck is a ground-based mission.
